Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Graph Theory, Combinatorics, and Abstract Algebra
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant funds the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in mathematics at the University of Texas at Tyler. The eight-week program will take place in the summers of 2017, 2018, and 2019. Each summer, nine students will work in groups of three with one faculty mentor leading each group. The program focuses on building confidence of student participants and preparing them to pursue careers in mathematics. The REU will have a greater effect by recruiting students from underrepresented groups. In particular, African Americans, Hispanics, women, and first-generation college students will be recruited.

The mentors for the REU site will provide research questions that are accessible to undergraduates, yet interesting to working mathematicians. The goal is to provide participants the opportunity to conduct original research leading to publication in professional journals. The research projects are in the areas of graph theory, combinatorics, and abstract algebra. All topics will be accessible to students who have taken early proof-based mathematics courses. By the end of the eight weeks, REU students will write their results in a professional format and prepare a final talk and a poster suitable for presentation at the Joint Mathematics Meetings in January.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Texas at Tyler is to increase the participation of underrepresented groups in mathematical research and graduate training. Additionally, the REU seeks to teach research skills to undergraduates who typically would not be exposed to research until graduate school. Finally, the REU site at the University of Texas at Tyler sets the goal of increasing the number of qualified undergraduates choosing to pursue graduate degrees in mathematics.

The REU accomplished its goal of recruiting at least two-thirds of its participants from groups that are underrepresented in mathematics. Over the three year program, 22 of 27 students (81%) reported themselves to be from one or more of the following groups: Hispanic, African American, Native American, female, or first-generation college student.

Another goal of the REU is for at least half of its participants to pursue a PhD in mathematics within 2 years of graduating. Currently, 12 of 21 students who have graduated are enrolled in graduate school.

The student researchers who participated in the REU were very productive. Each of the research groups presented a poster at the Joint Mathematics Meetings which are held in January each year. One poster was awarded Outstanding Poster by a panel of mathematicians. Additionally, many students gave talks based on their research at various conferences throughout the year following their participation in the REU. Finally, six papers originating from the REU have been accepted by peer-reviewed mathematics journals and at least one more should be submitted before the end of the year.
